audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Reading & Writing)

teacher_notes.pacing: 45–60 minutes; 3 short sections with brief checks for understanding.
teacher_notes.materials: Slides or handout with overview charts, timer, projector, and printed practice questions.
teacher_notes.assessment: Exit ticket plus 4-item unit check; informal cold-calls during quick checks.

learning_objectives: Describe the structure and purpose of the SAT Reading & Writing module.
Explain scoring, timing, and adaptive modules.
Recognize common passage types and question categories.
Apply a simple read–predict–select routine to short SAT items.

structure.title: Overview of the Test
objectives: Identify the module format and navigation basics.
Understand that questions are discreet and multiple-choice (A–D).

lecture_script.script: The digital SAT Reading & Writing has two adaptive modules with short passages and one question each. All items are multiple-choice A–D, and you may flag and return within a module.
I skim the passage first for the gist, predict the answer in a few words, then match that prediction to the option that best fits while eliminating distractors.
We’ll try one item together. I’ll model how to underline the key claim and test each option against that claim.
Thumbs: Who feels clear on the module structure and the read–predict–select routine?

worked_example.passage: Maya arranged the lab samples methodically, noting that careful order reduced mistakes and sped analysis. Her mentor watched, smiling at the quiet efficiency.
worked_example.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the passage?

options.B: The mentor corrects Maya’s inefficient method.
options.C: Maya’s organized approach improves accuracy and speed.
options.D: The lab is too noisy for careful work.

worked_example.explanation: The passage emphasizes that order reduces mistakes and speeds analysis, showing organization improves accuracy and speed.

structure.title: Scoring & Timing
objectives: Allocate time per question using benchmarks.
Practice skipping, flagging, and returning efficiently.

lecture_script.script: Your Reading & Writing section score ranges from 200–800. Manage time by aiming for a steady pace and using flags to revisit tougher items within a module.
If an item feels sticky after 20–30 seconds, I pick the best option so far, flag it, and move on to protect later points.
We’ll simulate two quick items with a visible timer and practice making fast, confident choices.
What’s our rule when stuck: guess-and-flag or dwell? State it in one phrase.

worked_example.passage: Because the conference schedule was dense, Jordan reviewed abstracts the night before to decide which talks to attend first.
worked_example.question: What strategy does Jordan use to manage limited time?
worked_example.explanation: Jordan previews abstracts to prioritize, mirroring time management and prioritization.

structure.title: Types of Passages & Questions
objectives: Recognize literary, historical, scientific, and informational passages.
Identify common question types (main idea, evidence, words in context).

lecture_script.script: Expect brief literary, historical, scientific, and informational texts. Questions target main ideas, evidence, words in context, structure, and standard English conventions.
We’ll examine a trap answer that is true but not relevant, and show why relevance to the question is essential.
Let’s label the passage type and question type before choosing an answer.
Write one sentence naming a passage type and the best first step you’d take.

worked_example.passage: In 1913, the suffragists’ parade drew national attention, transforming a local campaign into a movement that pressed lawmakers to act.
worked_example.question: Which choice best captures the central idea?

options.B: A 1913 parade amplified a political movement.

worked_example.explanation: The sentence says the parade drew attention and transformed the campaign, amplifying the movement.
